positive.review: The game is mostly successful due to the void of the category on steam, and it would be a lot better if they made the strike zone more dynamic rather than a ball garunteed to be either a dinky grounder or a foul ball, regardless of how close the ball is to the strike zone, it just makes it less immersive and more frusterating as a hitter. I do enjoy the pitching and general progression of the game though, it is very p2w but it is possible to take it slowly and progress. The overall team building of the game is where it shines though, as it can be very engaging to make the best team possible. Also, if I had to change one thing about the game, it would be making the league mode teams actually perform to the reccommended OVR that it says on the UI, for reference the Champion 2 league option has a reccommended OVR of 115, however some of the highest teams in the mode will have OVRs of 128, it just doesnt make any sense and it is frusterating to me as a player since my OVR is about 124 and I cant progress past a challenge mode supposedly made for players at 115 OVR. But the game is pretty solid overall.

It really blows that the best options for PC Baseball games are either Backyard Baseball '97 or MLB Rivals. That being said, it's pretty clear why Rivals is so good despite literally being a mobile to PC port. Com2uS (formerly Gamevil) has been developing baseball games going back as far as at least 2007 with Baseball Superstars 2007. They've since ditched the cutesy, anime-like artstyle for an MLB license and pretty good graphics for a mobile game and present more of the same fun and engaging gameplay and modes to keep you coming back.

Of course, the game has microtransactions but so far in my 11 hours I've amassed a quite nice roster (Mookie, Soto, Jeter, Chisholm, Ohtani, Freeman, Devers, Acuna, etc.) without spending a dime and just by playing and picking the right card packs. I wish the pop ups for $20 bundles and other things weren't so predatory but hey, mobile game things.

Overall, it's a fun game and worth looking at. I just really hope someday MLB The Show can come to PC or some dev/dev team could make a truly excellent baseball game.

I've put nearly 1,200 hours into this game and while I can say it had it's moments and consumed time for me when I was bored. But it's an unrewarding and exhausting experience. Through my entire time put into this game I've probably done well over 95% of the events throughout it. Putting time into the game you can gain quite a bit and actually find some solid enjoyment in it but if you don't spend money you will be completely outmatched when you start to stagnate. Yes I understand this is a gacha game and I should be expected to spend money but with the amount of time I've put in with events and other activities no matter how much you do you will find yourself in a completely outmatched environment if you do not spend money every time. 

I'm 100% complaining due to the lack of the show support on PC too and I wish for a better MLB experience but this is just not it. Spending money on a game is fine but to make such an effort in limiting your progress by so much even with the amount of time you put in just makes it an overall sad experience. 

Now am I saying don't play this game? No. If you find yourself bored it's definitely passes the time for you. But if you want to be able to reach the top without spending money you won't, or it will take an extremely long time. My experience is mixed, I hated not being able to progress much after reaching a certain point regardless of how much effort I put into the minigames and events. But it was able to pass time for me whenever I needed it to. That's all it'll be. Can't be bothered to spend hundreds of dollars just to progress at where I am.

It's a pay-to-win baseball gacha with minimal depth that thrives due to a lack of market competitors.  There is a definite hard cap to how far one can progress their team without sinking hundreds of dollars into incremental gains required to compete at the top levels.  Virtually every game milestone is met with a helpful opportunity to purchase another gacha box.

Maybe someday, MLB The Show will come back to PC.  Until then, this is a flawed option and if obtained you should become accustomed to getting your teeth kicked in unless you are willing to make a significant financial investment in the game.

I've put nearly 1,200 hours into this game and while I can say it had it's moments and consumed time for me when I was bored. But it's an unrewarding and exhausting experience. Through my entire time put into this game I've probably done well over 95% of the events throughout it. Putting time into the game you can gain quite a bit and actually find some solid enjoyment in it but if you don't spend money you will be completely outmatched when you start to stagnate. Yes I understand this is a gacha game and I should be expected to spend money but with the amount of time I've put in with events and other activities no matter how much you do you will find yourself in a completely outmatched environment if you do not spend money every time. 

I'm 100% complaining due to the lack of the show support on PC too and I wish for a better MLB experience but this is just not it. Spending money on a game is fine but to make such an effort in limiting your progress by so much even with the amount of time you put in just makes it an overall sad experience. 

Now am I saying don't play this game? No. If you find yourself bored it's definitely passes the time for you. But if you want to be able to reach the top without spending money you won't, or it will take an extremely long time. My experience is mixed, I hated not being able to progress much after reaching a certain point regardless of how much effort I put into the minigames and events. But it was able to pass time for me whenever I needed it to. That's all it'll be. Can't be bothered to spend hundreds of dollars just to progress at where I am.
